body_content.explanation: the part of the body above the neck where the eyes, nose, mouth, ears, and brain are:
examples: Put this hat on to keep your head warm.
He banged his head on the car as he was getting in.
She thought for a while, and then nodded/shook her head (= showed her agreement/disagreement).

body_content.explanation: a person or animal when considered as a unit:
examples: Dinner will cost Â£20 a/per head (= for each person).
I did a quick head count (= calculated how many people there were).
They own a hundred head of cattle (= 100 animals).

body_content.explanation: a measure of length or height equal to the size of a head:
examples: Her horse won by a head.
Paul is a head taller than Andrew.

body_content.explanation: the mind and mental abilities:
examples: You need a clear head to be able to drive safely.
What put that (idea) into your head? (= What made you think that?)
I can't get that tune/that man out of my head (= I cannot stop hearing the tune in my mind/thinking about that man).
Use your head (= think more carefully)! Control your emotions and think before you speak.
Harriet has a (good) head for figures (= she is very good at calculating numbers).
Do you have a head for heights (= are you able to be in high places without fear)?

body_content.explanation: someone in charge of or leading an organization, group, etc.:
examples: the head of the History department
the head chef
his first season as head coach

body_content.explanation:
a 
headteacher UK
a boy or girl who often represents his or her school on formal occasions:
examples: We are delighted to announce that Dominic Carter will be our next head boy.

body_content.explanation: the top part or beginning of something:
examples: the head of the queue
the head of the page
Diana, the guest of honour, sat at the head of the table (= the most important end of it).

body_content.explanation: the larger end of a nail, hammer, etc.
the top part of a plant where a flower or leaves grow:
examples: a head of lettuce

body_content.explanation: the layer of white bubbles on top of beer after it has been poured
the upper part of a river, where it begins
the top part of a spot when it contains pus (= yellow liquid)
the side of a coin that has a picture of someone's head on it:
examples: Heads won, so our team got to decide who played first.

body_content.explanation: the part of a tape or video recorder (= machine for recording sound or pictures) that touches the tape to record and play music, speech, etc.
the main part of the phrase, to which the other parts are related
a narrow area of high land that sticks out into the sea:
examples: the chalk cliffs around Beachy Head

body_content.explanation: to go in a particular direction:
examples: I was heading out of the room when she called me back.
We were heading towards Kumasi when our truck broke down.
He headed straight for (= went towards) the fridge.
I think we ought to head back/home (= return to where we started) now, before it gets too dark.

body_content.explanation: to be in charge of a group or organization:
examples: She heads one of Britain's leading travel firms.
Judge Hawthorne was chosen to head the team investigating the allegations of abuse.

body_content.explanation: to be at the front or top of something:
examples: The royal carriage headed the procession.
Jo's name headed the list of candidates.

body_content.explanation: to hit a ball with your head:
examples: Rooney headed the ball into the back of the net.

body_content.explanation: a person with a particular strong interest or addiction:
examples: a crack-head (= someone who depends on the drug crack)
